column1: Poway  is a city in San Diego County
column2: California
column3: United States. The unincorporated community became a city on December 1
column4: 1980.    Poway's rural roots gave rise to its slogan "The City in the Country". As of the 2010 census
column5: the city had a population of 47
column6: 811.Poway is north of the city of San Diego and south of the city of Escondido. Nearby communities include Rancho Bernardo
column10: and Ramona to the east. Poway is considered part of San Diego's North County. According to the United States Census Bureau
column11: the city has a total area of 39.3 square miles (102 km2)
column12: of which 0.1 square miles (0.26 km2) (0.25%) is water.

column2: spear points
column5: and pottery found along the bed of Poway Creek all indicate an early Diegueño presence. Various pictographs adorn many of Poway's boulders
column6: and modern dating techniques suggest these paintings date to the 16th century and earlier.The original name of the valley ("Pawiiy" or "Pauwai") is derived from the Kumeyaay language of the Kumeyaay people who roamed the area for several hundred years before the Spaniards colonised the region. Traces of these Native Americans still remain in Diegueño.

column2: the Mission San Diego de Alcalá kept cattle in the valley. Documents of Mission San Diego de Alcala record the name of the valley as "Paguay" as early as 1828. Though there is a discrepancy on the exact translation of "Paguay
column3: the generally accepted version indicates the meeting of little valleys" or "end of the valley." Some controversy also surrounds the proper spelling; historically it has also been written by the Mexican authorities as Paguai. It has also been written as Paui
column7: Poway served as a stock range for the mission and local ranchos. In September 1839
column8: Corporal Rosario Aguilar was granted Rancho Paguai a ranch in the valley and it was confirmed on May 22
column11: becoming Juez de paz in 1841 and moving instead to San Juan Capistrano.

column1: American settlers began to come to the valley for farming purposes in the late antebellum period. Few records of this time have survived
column2: and not until 1894 and the inception of the Poway Progress did the town's history become a thing of record. In 1887
column3: about 800 people lived and farmed in Poway. Around the start of the 20th century
column4: Poway farmers had moderate success in the production and vending of fruit

column1: Poway has a creek and fertile soil
column2: but the lack of easily available water prevented the settlement from attracting large-scale farmers and the accompanying population growth. In 1954 the Poway Municipal Water District was established to utilize water from the Colorado River Aqueduct  . In 1957

column1: In 1980 Poway incorporated and was nicknamed "the City in the Country". Poway no longer relies on agriculture for its primary source of income and has instead transitioned into a residential community for those who work for employers in and around the San Diego area. According to a recent state government estimate
column2: the population of Poway has grown since that last census to 50
column3: 542. It has been designated a "Tree City" for the last decade.

column1: Major portions of the town were evacuated during both the 2003 Cedar Fire and 2007 Witch Creek Fire.In 2004

column4: based out of nearby Camp Pendleton. The Fred L. Kent Post 7907 of the Veterans of Foreign Wars has been the official go-between with the battalion
column5: which has been redeployed at least once to Iraq since its adoption.

column1: The town's roots lie in agriculture. The Homestead Act of 1862 encouraged Westward migration
column2: and accordingly many of Poway's first white settlers came to farm. The fecund soil proved well-suited to a variety of crops
column8: and alfalfa. Some farmers captured swarms of wild bees and cultivated honey. Dairying also proved lucrative. Most families kept a cow for milk and butter
column10: and perhaps a hog to sustain them while they farmed. Crops sold well around the San Diego area. Between the seasons of 1894 and 1896
column11: the Poway Progress reported bits of agricultural information such as:

column1: Muscat grapes are beginning to ripen
column2: and the San Diego market is getting a supply of the fine article Poway always produces. ... The season has been a prolific one for bees
column3: thirty of forty stands the present season from a single captured swarm a year or two ago. ... The peach is a good article
column4: and Poway produces it to perfection. Poway pears will compare with any grown in the state.

column1: The success of these crops depended on the annual winter rainfall
column2: however
column3: and so remained subject to variations in precipitation until the establishment of the Poway Municipal Water District in 1954. With water readily available
column4: the town's farming interest shifted to two principal crops: avocados and citrus fruits. With water came new residents
column5: and the former farm town transformed into a locale full of small commercial businesses and modest shopping centers.

column1: Poway established its school district in 1871
column2: but did not have a schoolhouse until 1885
column3: when a one-room school was built at Midland Road about a 2–3-minute walk south of the Templar's Hall. The site is still in use today as an elementary school (Kindergarten through 5th grade)
column4: though it was torn down and rebuilt in 1945
column5: and renovated again in 2004–2006. First through eighth graders were included in one classroom. Children learned to read and write using slates
column6: and eventually progressed to study subjects such as arithmetic
column12: and geography. Students did not usually attend high school
column13: and had to travel to Escondido if they wished to do so. In 1909
column14: only three students from Poway graduated from high school. Women who went on to more school from there usually had teaching ambitions. Education
column15: while compulsory and considered a worthwhile pastime
column16: had few far-reaching applications for Poway's farmers' children. Enrollment in the Poway School 1st–8th grades did not reach 100 until 1932.

column1: Poway's transportation history parallels that of early California. In 1888 the first stagecoach began to service the towns from San Diego to Escondido
column2: including Poway. The stage made one stop in town
column4: and also delivered mail to the farmers who would wait along the road for its arrival. The men would trot alongside the coach and inquire as to the state of the mail
column5: and thus receive letters without requiring it to stop. Eight to ten passengers could accompany the stagecoach on its three-day journey for a modest $1.00 fee
column6: or purchase a round trip for the bargain price of $1.50. The route itself
column7: though not treacherous when passing through Poway
column8: did pose a significant challenge to the team and driver at various points. Windy mountain trails often caused the stage to turn over
column9: spilling both mail and passengers onto the rocky turf. The city of San Diego discontinued the stage line in 1912
column10: when the advent of the automobile facilitated an easier and less time-consuming method of mail delivery. Poway established a County Road Station in 1920
column11: to oil and maintain the roads so that automobiles could use them with ease. The road station remained in operation until 1961
column12: when Poway achieved an 80% paved road rate. To this day
column14: the town still boasts a number of dirt roads
column18: and pedestrians. Portions of what is currently Pomerado Road
column20: were once U.S. Route 395 in California.North County Transit District (NCTD) operates public transportation routes 944 and 945 connecting the City of Poway to the adjacent transit centers of Sabre Springs and Rancho Bernardo.

column1: Poway's greatest change started in the 1950s when water came to the valley. On January 29

column8: the citizens voted to incur bonded debt of $600
column9: 000 to build a water system. The first water delivery was made in July 1954 to Gordon's Grocery on Garden Road. In 1972 Poway Dam was built to provide a dependable supply of water.In 1957

column14: Poway Municipal Water and Pomerado County Water

column1: Poway incorporated as a general law city in December 1980. Like most California cities
column2: it uses a council/manager form of government. City policies are set by a five-member city council which includes a directly-elected mayor. The mayor and councilmembers are elected at-large to overlapping four-year terms. Council appoints the deputy mayor
Poway is in the  38th Senate District
column5: represented by Democrat Brian Maienschein.In the United States House of Representatives
column6: Poway is in California's 52nd congressional district
column7: which has a Cook PVI (partisan voting index) of D+6 and is represented by Democrat Scott Peters.
